--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> Wh=
en I wrote _JUnit Recipes_, my examples used EasyMock. I liked it 
> becaus=
e it was simple for the simplest case of setting expectations.
> 
> When I =
started using jMock, I much preferred it, because:
> 
> 1. It has direct su=
pport for fakes/stubs.

EasyMock 1 had default return values/throwables for=
 that,
EasyMock 2 has stub return values/throwables for that.

> 2. It make=
s ignoring method parameters easy.

I agree, This was a major pain in EasyM=
ock 1.
The rationale behind this was that I found no way to make
this refac=
toring-safe (reordering parameter refactorings should
not break the test). =
In EasyMock 2, matchers can be defined
directly in the method calls, allowi=
ng to ignore arguments,
match only parts of an argument, and so on. 
You ma=
y even define your own matchers.

> 3. Its support for complex parameter, m=
ethod or invocation matching is 
> great.

EasyMock 2 has much better suppo=
rt for that. Argument matchers
are in my opinion better. Inter-mock depende=
ncies can be defined.

> If there is ever a 2nd edition of _JUnit Recipes_,=
 I will replace all 
> the EasyMock example code with jMock.

As the author=
 of EasyMock, I am sad to hear that.
Can you elaborate which features are m=
issing in 
EasyMock 2 that are so crucial that you consider switching?

> T=
he people who don't like jMock often say it's because declaring the 
> meth=
od names as strings makes refactoring more error-prone. That might 
> be th=
e case, but I have never felt pain as a result of it.

It's not only a prob=
lem when renaming methods. 

Reordering, adding, or removing parameters all=
 break tests at runtime, 
and you have to adapt them manually to the new si=
tuation. 
Tests using EasyMock work after reordering and removing
parameter=
s, and after adding parameters if no matchers were used.

And there is also=
 the issue of code completion when defining expectations.
With JMock, it do=
es not work, you have to rely on text completion features.
With EasyMock, i=
t works like a charm.

-
Tammo Freese
